meanings.def: a number of people standing or sitting next to each other in a line; a number of objects arranged in a line
examples: row of somebody/something There is a row of trees in front of the house.
in a row We sat in a row at the back of the room.
The vegetables were planted in neat rows.
row upon row of somebody/something He looked down at row upon row of eager faces.
He gave me a single red rose.
Prices rose 2 per cent in December.
Five rows of chairs were set out facing the whiteboard.
She rows across the river, helping passengers reach the other side.
She arranged the chairs in two neat rows.
The children stood in a row.
endless rows of identical houses

meanings.def: a line of seats in a cinema, theatre, etc.
examples: in the… row Let's sit in the back row.
We have seats in the front row.
Our seats are five rows from the front.

meanings.def: a line of numbers or words arranged one after the other across the page in a table
examples: The top row of Table 2 shows the current values.
There are eight rows and four columns in the table.
You can insert rows between existing ones.

meanings.def: a complete line of stitches in knitting or crochet (= ways of making clothing, etc. out of wool)
used in the name of some roads
examples: Manor Row
I live at 22 Western Row.

meanings.def: an act of rowing a boat; the period of time spent doing this
examples: We went for a row on the lake.

meanings.def: to have made all the preparations needed to do something; to be well organized
examples: The company has its ducks in a row for a move into the Asian market.
Get your ducks in a row before you retire.

meanings.def: if something happens several times in a row, it happens in exactly the same way each time, and nothing different happens in the time between
examples: This is her third win in a row.

meanings.def: if something happens for several days, etc. in a row, it happens on each of those days
examples: Inflation has fallen for the third month in a row.
It rained for five days in a row.

idioms.idiom: get/have (all) your ducks in a row
idioms.def: to have made all the preparations needed to do something; to be well organized
examples: The company has its ducks in a row for a move into the Asian market.
Get your ducks in a row before you retire.

idioms.def: if something happens several times in a row, it happens in exactly the same way each time, and nothing different happens in the time between
examples: This is her third win in a row.
Inflation has fallen for the third month in a row.
It rained for five days in a row.

meanings.def: to move a boat through water using oars (= long thin straight pieces of wood with flat ends)
examples: We rowed around the island.
row something Grace rowed the boat out to sea again.
Follow the road around to the left.
I rode a camel when I was on holiday.
She took the oars and rowed quickly down the river.
He gave me a single red rose.
Prices rose 2 per cent in December.
Five rows of chairs were set out facing the whiteboard.
She rows across the river, helping passengers reach the other side.

meanings.def: to take somebody somewhere in a boat with oars
examples: The fisherman rowed us back to the shore.

meanings.def: a serious argument between people, organizations, etc. about something
examples: A row has broken out over education.
A row blew up over pay rises for ministers.
He came to prominence in the row over defence policy.
a row between the left and right wings of the party

meanings.def: a noisy argument between two or more people
examples: She left him after a blazing row.
family rows
He had a row with his son.
Carol and I had a terrible row about how much money she spends.
We were unable to rouse him from his sleep.
They keep having rows over who does more work around the house.
Who's making that row?
Someone's making an unholy row outside.
I'm going to kick up a row if I don't get my money back.
Mike and Sue are always rowing.
row (with somebody) (about somebody/something) She had rowed with her parents about her boyfriend.
